materials.name: 6061 aluminum
materials.summary: Sharp HSS/cobalt; mid RPM; WD-40/Tap Magic Alu. Make curls, not dust.
drilling: Medium speed (250â€“400 SFM press; mid RPM hand drill).
Sharp HSS/cobalt; split-point; stub length.
WD-40 / Tap Magic Alu; air blast.
tapping: Spiral-point (through) / spiral-flute (blind).
Form taps OK with proper drill.
holesaw: Bi-metal 10â€“14 TPI or carbide; WD-40; peck; backer for thin sheet.
notes: If it squeals, youâ€™re rubbingâ€”slow RPM or add feed.

materials.name: 7075 aluminum
materials.summary: Cooler & sharper than 6061; step-up sizing; lube helps.
drilling: Slightly slower vs 6061; avoid galling.
Sharp tools; step up for accuracy; lube helps.
tapping: Spiral-point (through) / spiral-flute (blind). Form taps OK.
holesaw: Run cooler than 6061; lube generously; carbide hole saw preferred for repeat work.

materials.name: mild steel
materials.summary: HSS/cobalt; low RPM; steady feed; cutting oil. Break chips on deep holes.
drilling: Low speed (70â€“100 SFM), firm feed.
135Â° split-point HSS/cobalt.
Cutting oil; break chips on deep holes.
tapping: Spiral-point (through) / spiral-flute (blind); oil.
Back tap to break chips.
holesaw: Carbide or fresh bi-metal; LOW RPM; steady feed; flood oil. >2 in: consider annular cutter.

materials.name: 4130 chromoly
materials.summary: Treat like tough mild steel; low speed; good oil.
drilling: Low speed; firm feed; cobalt helpful for repeat ops.
tapping: Generous oil; donâ€™t bottom with chips packed in flutes.
holesaw: Carbide hole saw; oil; low RPM; firm feed; spot/pilot first.

materials.name: 300 stainless
materials.summary: Very low RPM, firm feed; no dwell. Cobalt/carbide; sulfurized oil.
drilling: Very low speed (25â€“40 SFM). Keep feed onâ€”no hovering.
Cobalt or carbide; stub preferred.
Coolant/oil. Never dwell.
tapping: Sharp taps, sulfurized oil, short bursts.
If it squeaks, you work-hardenedâ€”re-spot.
holesaw: Prefer carbide; very low RPM; sulfurized oil; keep cuttingâ€”donâ€™t rub.

materials.name: g10 hardpoint (helicoil)
materials.summary: Use STI taps + coils (M4â€“M10 typical). Drill clean, tap square, install to depth.
drilling: Spot, pilot, then STI tap drill; perpendicular; deburr lightly.
tapping: Use STI taps; install Helicoil 0â€“0.5 pitch below surface.
holesaw: Carbide-grit or sharp carbide; moderate RPM; dust extraction.

materials.name: richlite
materials.summary: Lowâ€“med RPM; pilot then final; back exit. Treat like dense hardwood.
drilling: Lowâ€“med RPM; sharp bits; pilot then final; back exit to avoid chipping.
tapping: Cut tap with light oil or use inserts; test first.
holesaw: Treat like dense hardwood: sharp, moderate RPM; backer; vacuum dust.
notes: Smells like toasted shop class. Vent!

materials.name: plywood (baltic birch)
materials.summary: High RPM; brad-point; back the exit. Consider shank clearance.
drilling: High RPM; brad-point; clamp/backer; avoid veneer blow-out.
tapping: Use inserts; tapping wood is last resort.
holesaw: Sharp teeth; backer; drill until pilot breaks through, flip, finish from other side.

materials.name: cfrp laminate
materials.summary: Low RPM, carbide composite/brad/step drills; back both sides; tape face; vacuum; feather exit. Avoid heat and dwell.
drilling: Use sharp carbide composite/brad-point or step drills; minimal pilot to avoid wandering.
Clamp with sacrificial backer (top & bottom if possible); tape the face; support exit.
Low RPM, steady feed; light peck only to clear chips; vacuum extraction (P100).
For pristine holes: pilot undersize and finish with diamond reamer or countersink to break fibers.
tapping: Avoid tapping laminate; use hardpoints/inserts (G10 or metal) or STI + Helicoil.
If forced to tap thick quasi-isotropic plate: use composite taps, very low RPM, short advances, expect limited strength.
holesaw: Diamond-grit or fine-tooth carbide hole saw; composite SFM ~40â€“80; low RPM, steady feed.
Tape both sides; sandwich between backers; drill from each face to avoid blow-out; vacuum dust.
notes: Carbon dust is conductiveâ€”keep it away from electronics and harnesses.
Seal exposed edges if needed (thin epoxy wick) to prevent moisture ingress and fraying.
Avoid oily coolants before bonding; keep surfaces clean (IPA) if parts will be bonded.

materials.name: foam core carbon panel
materials.summary: Light pressure, sharp bits, solid backer. Tape faces, support exit, and seal any exposed core. Pot hardpoints for structural fasteners.
drilling: Pilot minimal, then final size with carbide composite/brad/step drill.
Use backers on both sides; tape faces; feather the exit to prevent delam.
Low RPM, steady feed; vacuum extraction (P100).
tapping: Do not tap skins/core for structureâ€”use G10/metal hardpoints and STI/Helicoil after cure.
If a light-duty thread is unavoidable: composite tap, very low RPM, short advances; treat as non-structural.
holesaw: Diamond-grit or fine-tooth carbide; composite SFM ~40â€“80 â†’ low RPM.
Sandwich between backers; tape both sides; drill partway, flip, finish from opposite face.
Seal exposed core with thin epoxy.
notes: Keep carbon dust away from electronicsâ€”itâ€™s conductive.
Avoid oily coolants prior to bonding; clean with IPA if bonding is planned.

materials.name: foam core fiberglass panel
materials.summary: Treat like a delicate sandwich: sharp tool, low RPM, full support, and edge sealing. Use potting or hardpoints for fasteners.
drilling: Slow RPM, sharp composite/brad/step drills; minimal pecking.
Backer board under work; tape faces; ease the exit to prevent chipping.
Vacuum dust; PPE (P100).
tapping: Avoid tapping laminate or core; use bonded inserts or potted hardpoints for load-bearing hardware.
holesaw: Carbide-grit or fine-tooth; low RPM; steady feed.
Tape both sides; backer; drill from both faces to reduce blow-out.
Seal exposed foam with epoxy.
notes: Keep heat downâ€”resin softens and smears when overheated.
If the hole edges fuzz, kiss with a countersink just enough to break fibers.

materials.name: PETG
materials.summary: More ductile than acrylic, less notch-sensitive than PC. Cut itâ€”donâ€™t melt it. Keep chips moving.
drilling: Medium RPM, sharp plastic-geometry or step bits; lightâ€“moderate feed.
Clear chips often to avoid heat buildup; short pecks only.
Support exit side; masking tape on face helps reduce scuffing.
tapping: Thread-forming taps work well (no chips).
If cutting taps are used: very low RPM, minimal torque, consider inserts for durability.
holesaw: Fine-tooth or plastic-rated hole saw; lowâ€“moderate RPM; gentle feed.
Pause to cool if chips smear; use air blastâ€”avoid oils that can affect bonding/finishing.
notes: Avoid solvent exposure near edges you plan to bond or finish.
If the hole looks glossy and smeared, youâ€™re meltingâ€”slow RPM and increase chipload slightly.
materials.tapType: Form tap preferred; inserts for repeated service

materials.name: wood-laminated foam core fiberglass panel
aliases: wood veneer over GFRP foam core
materials.summary: Veneer + fiberglass over foam: protect the veneer face, support both sides, and pot or use hardpoints where hardware lands.
drilling: Pilot through the veneer with a sharp brad-point, then open to size with a composite/step bit to avoid tearing fibers.
Clamp with sacrificial backers; tape faces; finish from both sides for clean edges.
Keep RPM modest to limit heat in resin layers.
tapping: Do not tap into veneer/foam skins; use potted inserts (epoxy) or embedded G10/wood hardpoints.
For hinges/handles: over-bore the core locally and pot a dense insert before final drilling.
holesaw: Fine-tooth for the wood face; carbide-grit/fine-tooth through fiberglass.
Tape both faces; drill until pilot breaks through, flip, and complete from the opposite side.
Seal any exposed core and veneer edges.
notes: Pre-drill for screws in the veneer to prevent splitting; consider shank clearance.
Use structural epoxy for potting; scuff/clean bond areas.

sendCutSendBendSpecs._note: SCS air-bend specs. Bend radius is inside radius. Min flange = minimum leg after bend (outside dim from apex). Source: sendcutsend.com/bending-calculator
sendCutSendBendSpecs._solidworks: SCS SolidWorks gauge tables available at sendcutsend.com/blog/how-to-import-and-use-sheet-metal-gauge-tables-in-solidworks/

mildSteel.note: Large radius; verify with SCS calculator

stainless304.note: Springs back more than mild steel

aluminum5052.note: Larger radius; verify with SCS calculator

materials.name: Mild Steel (A36 / 1008)
materials.summary: The workhorse. Cheap, strong, welds beautifully, machines well. Goes rusty fast — plan your finish early.
bendingNotes: Radius ≈ 1× material thickness for soft bends; SCS uses fixed radii — always design to their spec.
Springback is modest — easier to hit angle than stainless.
Grain direction matters on tight bends: bend perpendicular to rolling direction if possible.
Min hole-to-bend distance: 2× material thickness + bend radius.
fabricationTips: Deburr cut edges before bending — sharp edges crack under forming pressure.
Weld distortion: tack sequence matters, weld from center out, use backstep on long seams.
Prime cut edges immediately if part will see any moisture.
For slotted/tabbed assemblies: design slots 0.005"–0.010" wider than tab for laser kerf.
weldingNotes: MIG: ER70S-6 wire, 75/25 Ar/CO2. Best all-around for A36/1008.
TIG: ER70S-2 filler. Cleaner welds, better for thin gauge (< 16ga).
Stick: E6013 for general, E7018 for structural.
Thin gauge (20ga–18ga): reduce heat, stitch weld, use backing bar to prevent burn-through.

materials.name: 304 Stainless Steel
materials.summary: Corrosion resistant, work-hardens fast, costs more, harder to weld. Don't use where mild steel + paint works fine.
bendingNotes: Springback is significant — SCS accounts for this in their tooling, but in-shop forming needs over-bend.
Bend radius must be LARGER than mild steel at same gauge — stainless cracks on tight radii.
Never bend across heavy mill scratches — they become cracks.
Work-hardens quickly: don't make multiple corrective bends in same area.
fabricationTips: Use stainless-only tooling and wire brushes — carbon steel contamination causes rust spots.
Protect finish during fab: leave plastic film on, use masking tape on contact surfaces.
Tabs and slots: design same 0.005"–0.010" clearance as mild steel — laser kerf is similar.
Passivate welded assemblies (citric acid bath) if corrosion resistance is critical.
weldingNotes: TIG preferred: ER308L filler for 304-to-304. Low heat input, back purge on critical joints.
MIG: ER308L, 98/2 Ar/O2. Less ideal than TIG but faster for thicker sections.
No galvanic mixing: don't use carbon steel wire on stainless.
Heat discoloration (sugaring) on back side = loss of corrosion resistance — back purge matters.

materials.name: 5052-H32 Aluminum
materials.summary: Best aluminum for sheet metal work. More formable than 6061, excellent corrosion resistance, welds well. SCS's go-to bending aluminum.
bendingNotes: DO NOT design 6061 for bending — it cracks. Use 5052 for any bent aluminum.
Bend across grain where possible (perpendicular to rolling direction) to reduce cracking risk.
Springback less than stainless but more than mild steel.
Min bend radius ≈ 1× material thickness for H32 temper.
fabricationTips: Slots and tabs: add 0.005"–0.010" clearance for laser kerf, same as steel.
Avoid iron contamination — use aluminum-only files and wire brushes.
Anodizing hides most surface scratches; powder coat requires proper etch and prime.
Self-tapping screws work well; for thread strength use Helicoil/STI inserts or rivet nuts.
weldingNotes: TIG: ER5356 filler (stronger) or ER4043 (flows better, less crack-prone). AC, 100% Argon.
MIG: ER5356 with spool gun. Push angle only, no pull.
Clean aggressively: IPA wipe then stainless brush, weld within minutes.
No hydrogen — no oil, no water, no paint near the joint.

materials.name: 6061-T6 Aluminum
materials.summary: Strong and machinable but DO NOT BEND — it cracks. Use for flat plate, machined parts, extrusions. Use 5052 for anything that bends.
bendingNotes: ⚠️ DO NOT BEND 6061-T6 — it will crack on any meaningful bend.
If you need a bent part in 6061, use 5052 instead.
Flat plate, gussets, tabs, machined brackets: 6061 is excellent.
Can be bent in annealed (O) temper but loses most of its strength.
fabricationTips: Machines beautifully — fast, clean chips, great surface finish.
Holes and counterbores: sharp HSS/cobalt bits, WD-40, mid RPM.
Tap with spiral-point (gun) taps. Always use Helicoil in structural tapped holes.
Avoid long thin features with laser cut — 6061 can warp from heat input.
weldingNotes: Weldable with TIG (ER4043 or ER5356) but heat-affected zone loses T6 strength.
Welded 6061 is effectively annealed at the joint — re-heat treat or redesign around it.
For structural joints, prefer bolted or bonded over welded.

materials.name: 4130 Chromoly Steel
materials.summary: High strength-to-weight. Used in roll cages, tubing, structural brackets. Needs post-weld stress relief or normalize for critical applications.
bendingNotes: More springback than mild steel — overbend slightly when forming in-shop.
Bend radius: min 3× material thickness for sheet to avoid work-hardening cracks.
SCS bend radii are conservatively sized for 4130 — follow their spec table.
fabricationTips: Normalize or stress-relieve after welding for fatigue-critical parts (heat to 1600°F, air cool).
Slots and tabs: same 0.005"–0.010" clearance as mild steel.
Cold working increases hardness — don't try to straighten bent tubing repeatedly.
weldingNotes: TIG preferred: ER80S-D2 or ER70S-2 filler. Preheat > 0.120" thick (200–300°F).
MIG: ER80S-D2. Less ideal due to heat input.
Normalize after welding for fatigue-critical or roll cage applications.
Thin wall tubing: low amperage, no gaps, purge ID on closed sections.

rules.label: Slot width for free fit
rules.note: Accounts for laser kerf (~0.005") and gives assembly clearance

rules.label: Slot width for snug fit
rules.note: Tight but hand-pressable — good for tacked assemblies

rules.label: Slot width for interference/press
rules.note: Laser kerf gives slight interference — test first

rules.label: Tab width tolerance (SCS)
rules.note: Always add clearance in the slot, not the tab

rules.label: Min slot width
rules.value: 1× material thickness or 0.040", whichever is greater
rules.note: Narrower than this and laser can't cleanly cut

rules.label: Tab length (into slot)
rules.note: Less than this and tab pulls out under load

rules.label: Corner relief on slots
rules.note: Prevents stress concentration at slot corners

rules.label: Hole-to-edge distance
rules.note: Closer than this and edge may distort

rules.label: Hole-to-bend distance
rules.note: Holes too close to bends distort during forming

rules.label: Hole-to-hole spacing
rules.note: Less than this risks tearing the web

rules.label: Countersink max depth
rules.note: Deeper risks breaking through on thin stock

rules.label: Tapped hole min thickness for SCS
rules.note: Thinner than this, use PEM nut or rivet nut instead

rules.label: When required
rules.value: Any time a bend runs to or near a cut edge or another feature
rules.note: Prevents tearing at the end of the bend

rules.label: Relief depth
rules.note: Must extend past the bend tangent line

rules.label: Relief shape
rules.note: Radiused end reduces stress concentration — preferred

flangeMinimums.title: Flange Length Minimums (SCS Air Bend)
flangeMinimums.note: These are the minimum formed flange lengths SCS can hold. Shorter flanges slip in the tooling. Always check SCS material page for exact values.

fabricationTipsGeneral.tip: Sheet metal has a rolling grain direction. Bending perpendicular to grain = less cracking risk. Bending parallel to grain = more crack risk on tight radii. Mark grain direction on your flat patterns for shop reference.
Weld distortion is a force of nature — plan for it, don't fight it. Tack sequence: start from center, work outward. For long seams, backstep or skip-weld. Fixture critical geometry before welding.
Bend before you drill holes near bends. Weld before you drill for hardware that goes into welded features. Machine last wherever possible. Finish last — don't powder coat then drill.
Always spec material AND temper AND finish: '5052-H32 aluminum, 0.080" sheet' — not just 'aluminum.' Different tempers have completely different forming behavior.

Download SCS's SolidWorks gauge tables — they encode the exact bend radius and K-factor so your flat patterns match what they actually produce. Link: sendcutsend.com/blog/how-to-import-and-use-sheet-metal-gauge-tables-in-solidworks/
Tabbed assemblies are faster to fixture than fully open assemblies. Design tab-and-slot wherever you need parts to self-locate before tacking. Saves jig time and improves repeatability.

SCS laser kerf is approximately 0.005"–0.008" depending on material and thickness. For precise fits, design to your nominal dims and add clearance in mating features (slots, pockets), not in the part itself.
Springback order (most to least): Stainless > 6061 (don't bend) > 4130 > 5052 aluminum > Mild Steel. In-shop forming on a press brake: over-bend 2–5° and test a sample before running a batch.

pemHardware._note: Penn Engineering self-clinching hardware. Hole sizes per PEM catalog. Always check PEM IFI/EPS spec sheet for your exact sheet material and thickness.

nuts.note: Install into punched or drilled hole; do not use with thin soft alum <0.040"

flushStuds.note: Hole must be clean — burr causes mis-clinch

generalNotes: Always verify hole size against the exact PEM part number callout — length variants sometimes have different requirements.
Sheet must meet minimum thickness for proper clinch engagement; too thin = spin-out.
Install with flat punch on head side, anvil on opposite; do NOT weld after installation.
For aluminum sheet use SS (stainless) series PEM; standard carbon steel PEM can gall in soft alum.
Deburr holes before installation — burrs prevent flush seating.

heatSetInserts._note: Heat-set brass inserts for FDM 3D-printed parts. Hole sizes are for printed or drilled holes. Always test on a sample — optimal hole size varies slightly by printer, material, and insert brand.

inserts.note: Small — easy to strip; use sparingly
Approx — verify with your insert supplier

materialNotes.PLA: Iron ~180–190°C. Heat slowly — PLA softens fast; easy to overshoot and deform.
materialNotes.PETG: Iron ~200–210°C. Most forgiving. Slight pull-out resistance better than PLA.
materialNotes.ASA: Iron ~220°C. Similar to ABS. Good UV/outdoor resistance.
materialNotes.PA/Nylon: Iron ~230–240°C. Excellent pull-out. Absorbs moisture — dry filament before printing.
materialNotes.PC: Iron ~240–260°C. Highest strength. Harder to insert without cracking part.

generalNotes: Print hole ~0.1–0.2 mm undersize vs. insert OD — tight enough to self-locate before heat.
Use a dedicated soldering iron tip or insert press for consistent depth and vertical alignment.
Insert should sit flush or 0.1–0.2 mm below surface; proud inserts cause assembly gaps.
Let cool fully before applying torque — 30–60 seconds minimum.
For blind holes, leave ≥1× insert length of solid material below the insert.
Torque limit: M3 ≈ 0.5–0.8 N·m in PETG; M4 ≈ 1.0–1.5 N·m. Never over-torque into plastic.

cncRouter._note: CNC router feeds & speeds. Chipload is king — dial RPM and feed to hit chipload target. Always run a test cut and listen: singing=good, screaming=too fast, rubbing/burning=too slow or dull bit.

default.name: Shop Router
default.notes: Adjust to your machine. Most ShopBot/Avid-style routers run 10k–18k for most work.

aluminum.label: Aluminum (6061 / 7075)
aluminum.lube: Air blast mandatory; misting (WD-40 / Kool Mist) strongly recommended
notes: O-flute (single-flute) is the go-to — large gullet clears chips before re-cut.
Chip evacuation is everything: re-cutting = heat = weld = snapped bit.
Ramp in at ≤2° or helical entry — never straight plunge into aluminum.
Start at the low chipload end; increase until you hear clean chip formation.
7075 is harder — stay at the low chipload end, freshest bits only.
No coolant? Air blast at minimum. WD-40 mist ideal. Never dry cut aluminum.

composite.label: CFRP / Fiberglass / G10 Composite

doc.note: Full depth one pass only with compression bit + backer; 50% for upcut

composite.lube: Dry — dust extraction ONLY. P100 respirator mandatory.
notes: Carbon dust is conductive — keep away from electronics and spindle bearings.
Compression bit: downcut top + upcut bottom = clean face both sides. Use backer.
Sacrificial spoilboard or MDF backer required — prevents blowout on exit face.
Vacuum extraction at point of cut. P100 mask for anyone in the room.
Carbide wears fast in abrasive CFRP — inspect edge after every few parts.
Foam-core panels: reduce DOC to 40% dia — foam deflects under aggressive cuts.
G10/FR4 is extremely abrasive — diamond bits last 3–5× longer than plain carbide.
Ramp or helical entry. Plunging through carbon creates dangerous heat spikes.

wood.label: Plywood / Baltic Birch

doc.note: Up to 1× dia in softer ply; 0.5× in hard-face ply

notes: Compression bit = clean top AND bottom face — ideal for visible cabinet/panel parts.
Upcut: best chip clearing, fuzzy top face. Downcut: clean top, poor chip clearing.
Baltic birch is consistent — push the high chipload end for throughput.
Tabs or vacuum hold-down critical on thin parts — movement ruins finish pass.
Climb cut finish pass removes fuzz left from conventional roughing.

wood_dense.label: Richlite / Dense Paper Composite

doc.note: Dense and hard — 40% dia max, lighter passes than wood

wood_dense.lube: Dry — good dust extraction. Smells strong — ventilate the shop.
notes: Treat like a very dense hardwood. More conservative than you'd expect.
Paper composite is abrasive — inspect bit edge frequently.
Fine pervasive dust — P100 mask and dust extraction.
Light climb cut finish pass gives a very clean edge.
Dull bit = rubbing = heat = glazed surface. No second chances — swap early.

plastic.label: PETG / ABS / Acrylic (General Thermoplastics)

doc.note: 0.5× dia max — plastics melt if heat builds

plastic.lube: Air blast helps. No flood coolant on PETG — thermal shock can crack part.
notes: Heat is the enemy — melted chips weld to the bit and part in seconds.
O-flute: big gullet clears chips before they re-melt. First choice for plastics.
Chips look melted/stringy? RPM too high or feed too slow — increase feed first.
PETG is gummier than ABS — push chipload high, keep RPM moderate.
Acrylic: slow RPM (12–16k), high feed, sharp bit only — brittle, chips at edges.
Ramp entry preferred — plunging generates a heat spike at entry.

foam_core.label: Foam Core Panels (light trimming / profiling)

doc.note: Foam deflects — light passes; backer required

notes: Foam core deflects under load — vacuum hold-down and backer board are critical.
Compression bit minimizes delamination at the skin-foam interface.
Keep DOC shallow — aggressive cuts delaminate skins from core.
Carbon-skinned panels: treat dust as CFRP — conductive, use P100.

steel.label: Mild Steel / 4130 (light profiling only — use VMC if possible)

doc.note: 10–15% dia ONLY — routers lack rigidity for steel

steel.lube: Cutting oil mandatory — flood preferred, mist minimum
notes: ⚠ CNC routers are NOT designed for steel. Only with rigid machine + short bit.
Very light passes only — deflection causes chatter and snapped bits instantly.
Flood coolant or cutting oil mist. Dry cut = immediate bit death.
4-flute carbide, shortest reach possible, max spindle RPM for rigidity.
Use a VMC or knee mill for anything beyond very light engraving/profiling.
Climb milling reduces cutting force — important given low machine rigidity.

fdm3dp._note: FDM 3D printing fits, tolerances, design rules, and shop tips. Based on 0.4mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer height baseline. Adjust for your specific printer calibration.

fitTable._note: Clearance PER SIDE (radial). Formula: baseMm + (nominalMm  scalePct/100). FDM baseline 0.2mm absolute + ~0.10.2% of dimension. Press fits stay flat  interference already fights machine tolerance floor.

loose.label: Loose / Free sliding
loose.use: Lids, covers, non-critical assembly. Easy hand assembly, slight wobble OK.

sliding.label: Sliding / Clearance
sliding.use: Moving parts, hinges, drawer slides. Assembles by hand, moves freely.

close.label: Close / Normal assembly
close.use: Snug assemblies, panel clips. Needs light pressure, no wobble.

transition.label: Transition fit
transition.use: Locating pins, alignment bosses. May be clearance or press depending on print variation.

press.label: Light press fit
press.use: Press-in pins, light retention. Needs force to assemble  test first.

hardPress.label: Hard press fit
hardPress.use: Permanent retention. High risk of cracking FDM parts  use sparingly.

snapFit.label: Snap-fit gap (FDM)
snapFit.use: Cantilever snap clips. Gap scales slightly with size; tighter for rigid materials.

bearingBore.label: Bearing bore (into print)
bearingBore.use: Press bearing into printed bore. Undersize by 0.050.1mm; test on scrap first.

threadInsert.label: Heat-set insert bore
threadInsert.use: See Insert Hole Calculator tab for per-size values.

holeCompensation._note: FDM holes always print UNDERSIZED due to STL polygon approximation and bead width. Apply these to your nominal hole dimension in CAD.

vertical.note: Hole axis along Z (vertical print). Add 0.2mm to nominal diameter in CAD.

horizontal.note: Hole axis horizontal (printed as bridge). Add 0.3–0.5mm; best to ream to final size.

holeCompensation.rule: When in doubt: model slightly oversize and ream to final dimension with a drill bit. Fastest, most reliable path to a good fit.

designRules.title: Wall Thickness
tips: Minimum = 3× nozzle diameter (0.4mm nozzle → 1.2mm min).
Thin walls warp and may not slice correctly — always check in slicer preview.
Taper thick-to-thin transitions gradually; sudden steps create internal stress concentrations.
Ribs and gussets add stiffness without adding bulk — preferred over solid thick walls.

designRules.title: Overhangs
tips: Design 45° chamfers instead of 90° overhangs — eliminates supports entirely.
Avoid supports on cosmetic surfaces; they leave witness marks.
PETG handles overhangs worse than PLA — needs slower outer wall speed and strong cooling.
For steeper angles: split the part, print separately, bond or snap together.
Teardrop hole profiles eliminate overhang issues on horizontal holes.

designRules.title: Bridging
tips: Good cooling is the #1 factor — slow bridging speed + strong part fan.
Orient parts so spans run across X rather than Y if your machine has better X cooling.
Teardrop or pointed-top hole profiles let you bridge to a point instead of a flat top.
First bridge layer is always worst — it sags slightly, improving with each layer above.

designRules.title: Holes & Bores
tips: FDM holes are ALWAYS undersized — STL tessellation creates a circumscribed polygon, not a true circle.
Best practice: model 0.2–0.4mm oversize, then ream to final diameter with a drill bit.
For precision bores (bearings, pins): print undersize, drill/ream to exact spec.
Avoid horizontal holes >6mm without supports — use teardrop geometry instead.
Don't model threads smaller than M5/#10; they won't work — use heat-set inserts.

designRules.title: Pins, Bosses & Posts
tips: Pins under 2mm are fragile and may not resolve correctly — use off-shelf pins instead.
Add a fillet at the pin root: stress concentrator without it, especially in Z-direction.
Bosses should be reinforced with gussets or ribs on 3+ sides.
For critical alignment: print the bore, drill to size, press in a metal or drill-rod pin.

designRules.title: Print Orientation

values.Layer delamination: Occurs at 1/10 to 1/3 bulk material strength

tips: Orient so primary load runs along XY layers, NOT across layer lines (Z direction).
Snap hooks, cantilever clips: orient so bending stress runs across XY layers.
Thin vertical walls: print standing up for better layer adhesion. Lying flat → weak.
Mating parts should print in similar orientation so thermal warping affects both equally.
Vertical threads (M5+) print better than horizontal — full profile on every layer.
Tall thin features: print with brim or alongside other parts for stability.

designRules.title: Elephant Foot & First Layer

values.Chamfer to fix: 0.3–0.5 mm × 45° on bottom edge in CAD
values.Live Z offset: Back off slightly if foot is pronounced

tips: First layer squish causes bottom edges to flare outward — 'elephant foot'.
For precision fits: add a 45° chamfer to the bottom edge of the part in CAD.
Alternatively: slightly reduce first-layer flow or increase live Z offset.
Elephant foot is worse on heated beds with high first-layer temps — tune per material.

designRules.title: Snap Fits

values.Taper ratio: Taper to 50–60% of root thickness at tip

tips: FDM snap fits are weaker in Z direction — orient cantilever beams in XY plane.
Add a generous fillet at the beam root — this is where snap fits break.
Taper the beam toward the tip for more uniform stress distribution.
Use PETG or TPU for repeated-cycle snap fits — PLA fatigues and cracks.
Test-print the snap feature in isolation before committing to full part.
0.5mm clearance per side is the FDM starting point; tighten to 0.3mm for stiffer materials.

designRules.title: Warping & Bed Adhesion
tips: Round sharp base corners — warp stress concentrates at sharp corners, rounds distribute it.
Brim is your best friend for flat parts: 5–10mm brim width dramatically reduces lifting.
ABS/ASA: use enclosure, glue stick on bed, and avoid drafts. Warp = heat differential.
PETG: less warp than ABS but first layer adhesion can be tricky — clean PEI bed, no spray.
Large flat parts: add mouse-ear brims at sharp corners for targeted help.
Hollow out thick flat sections to reduce thermal mass and differential cooling.

designRules.title: Text & Logos
tips: Embossed (raised) text is more readable than engraved (sunken) on FDM parts.
Bold fonts survive better than thin/serif fonts at small sizes.
Orient text-side up (not on build plate) for best surface resolution.
Stroke width under 0.8mm won't reliably print with 0.4mm nozzle.

PLA.notes: Best for prototypes, brackets, jigs. Not for high-heat or repeated flex.

PETG.notes: Best all-around for functional FDM parts. TruckHouse default for 3DP structural parts.

ABS.notes: Needs enclosure. Shrinks ~0.8% — add to press-fit calcs. Acetone-smoothable.

ASA.notes: ABS-like but UV stable — good for exterior/underhood parts. Needs enclosure.

TPU.notes: For seals, gaskets, bump stops. Shore 95A typical. Slow print speed.

Nylon.notes: Hygroscopic — dry before print. Best for gears, snap fits, high-cycle parts.

CF-PETG.notes: Stiff and light. Abrasive — use hardened nozzle. Brittle vs. plain PETG.

CF-Nylon.notes: Best structural FDM material. Hardened nozzle. Dry filament critical.

shopTips.tip: Always print a fit test token (20mm cube with bore) before committing to a full part. Costs 10 minutes of filament, saves hours of iteration.
FDM tolerance is printer-specific. Calibrate your horizontal expansion offset in the slicer for your machine+filament combo — it's the single biggest accuracy lever.
Holes shrink more than external features. Add 0.2mm (vert) to 0.4mm (horiz) to nominal hole diameter, then ream if precision matters.
Sand mating surfaces with 220 grit for a cleaner fit — FDM surfaces have micro-ridges from layer lines that add effective interference.
Warm a press-fit bore with a heat gun or hot air briefly — PETG softens slightly at 60°C, making press fits dramatically easier.
CA glue + accelerator bonds FDM-to-FDM and FDM-to-metal well. Rough both surfaces first. Gap-filling CA for loose fits.
Epoxy (structural) works well for permanent bonds. 30-min epoxy gives working time; use fixturing. Scuff surfaces, IPA wipe first.
Parts fail along layer lines under tensile load. If a bracket breaks, re-orient so layers run perpendicular to the primary load, not parallel.
Increase perimeter count (walls) before increasing infill for structural parts — perimeters carry load, infill mostly fills volume.
Heat-set inserts outperform tapped plastic for every threaded connection that will see real torque. Never strip a boss again.
Annealing PLA at 70°C for 30 min increases heat resistance and interlayer strength significantly — parts may warp slightly so use sparingly.
Dry your filament. PETG/Nylon/CF absorbed overnight humidity = bubbles, weak layers, stringing. Use a dehydrator or oven at 60–70°C for 4–8h.
Elephant foot ruins bottom-face press fits. Add a 0.3–0.5mm 45° chamfer to the bottom edge of any precision feature in CAD.
First layer is always the most critical. Z offset tuning time is never wasted — everything else depends on it.
Ironing (top surface pass) gives a near-injected finish on flat top faces. Set iron flow to 10–15%, slow speed. Game-changer for cosmetic parts.
Design for the removal of supports at the start, not as an afterthought. One orientation change often eliminates all support.
Split large assemblies into multiple printable sub-parts and bond together. Bonded seam is often stronger than a single large print with bad orientation.
Add assembly lead-ins (chamfers or tapers on insertion edges) to press-fit bores and snap fits — makes assembly dramatically easier.
For structural brackets: run a quick hand-force test on a prototype before finalizing. FDM is fast — iterate before installing on the truck.
